‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏ì‡∏∞‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ú‡∏π‡πâ‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏™‡πà‡∏ß‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ‡∏™‡πà‡∏ß‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏™‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏¢‡∏±‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏á‡∏•‡∏î‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏™‡∏µ‡πà‡∏¢‡∏á‡∏≠‡∏¢‡∏π‡πà‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÉ‡∏ï‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏á‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏Ç‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ó‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏≤‡∏¢

EN

Bitcoin has pulled back toward $85K with momentum softening, reinforcing a consolidation phase rather than a decisive trend move. Market conditions have deteriorated across all indicators with Spot CVD flipping negative, indicating sell-side dominance, and netflows reversing into outflow, signaling weaker institutional support. Despite futures open interest easing, long-side funding has surged, indicating renewed bullish demand. Options markets remain cautious with increased demand for downside protection. On-chain activity remains weak with low active addresses, transfer volume, and compressed fees, while profitability has deteriorated with supply in profit falling and realized losses rising. The market has shifted into a more defensive posture across spot, derivatives, and on-chain indicators. While leverage is beginning to cool, persistent sell-side pressure and rising hedging demand suggest the market remains fragile. Stabilization is dependent on returning demand and fading sell pressure, as market participants continue to de-risk amid these challenging conditions.

Key Points

  • Bitcoin pulled back toward $85K with softening momentum
  • Market conditions deteriorated with sell-side dominance in spot market
  • On-chain activity remains weak across metrics
  • Market has become more defensive across all indicators
  • Stabilization depends on returning demand and fading sell pressure

Article

Bitcoin has pulled back toward $85K over the past week, with momentum softening. Spot volume remains stable but subdued, reinforcing a consolidation phase rather than a decisive trend move. Overview Spot conditions have deteriorated, with Spot CVD flipping sharply negative and confirming a clear shift toward sell-side dominance. Netflows have also reversed into a sizeable outflow, signalling weaker institutional support and adding near-term overhead pressure. Derivatives positioning is mixed. Futures open interest has eased, suggesting a modest reduction in leverage, however long-side funding has surged, indicating renewed demand for bullish exposure. Perpetual CVD has collapsed into the lower band, reinforcing an increasingly defensive posture in leverage markets. Options markets remain cautious. Open interest has drifted slightly lower, while the volatility spread remains elevated relative to realised levels, despite compressing over the week. At the same time, 25-delta skew has risen sharply, signalling increased demand for downside protection. On-chain activity remains weak. Active addresses sit below the lower band, transfer volume is hovering near range lows, and fees have compressed, reflecting reduced block space demand. Profitability has also deteriorated, with supply in profit falling and realised losses rising, suggesting stress conditions are building as market participants de-risk. Overall, market conditions have shifted more defensive across spot, derivatives, and on-chain indicators. While leverage is beginning to cool, persistent sell-side pressure and rising hedging demand suggest the market remains fragile, with stabilisation dependent on demand returning and sell pressure fading.
